awd_abstract_narration:
Dispersive waves occur in a variety of physical systems such as nonlinear optics, atmosphere and ocean waves, and plasmas.  Often these waves exhibit resonant interactions, i.e., interactions of waves that oscillate at the same frequency.   Resonant interactions are of paramount importance in the long-time behavior of the waves present in the relevant physical system.  Resonances can cause the wave amplitude to grow or can lead to  genuine nonlinear behavior of solutions. It quantifies   the long-time effects of the nonlinearities present in the problem. In addition to resonance, dispersion (waves moving into different parts of space) plays a central role in the long-time behavior of solutions.  Dispersion often tames the effects of resonances by pushing resonant waves into different regions in space. It provides a mechanism to control the amplitude of resonant waves.  Thus, together with dispersion, resonances form the backbone of the analytical tools which have been developed to study stability of nonlinear waves. The development of the space-time resonance method is a corner stone in such an endeavor. It brings existing methods together in a new setting that extends their applicability far beyond what was previously possible. This method is still in development and has been extended far beyond its initial inception. Nevertheless, there is lots of progress that needs to be made.



This proposal is concerned with the study of propagation, interaction, and asymptotic behavior of small amplitude nonlinear waves.   The PI proposes  to study  the asymptotic behavior of  small solutions of  four  dispersive and hyperbolic problems.  The aim of the research is to develop new methods to determine the asymptotic behavior of such solutions.  The PI, in collaboration with others,  plans to consider problems when either  the energy or decay estimates are weak, i.e., non-integrable, or when  the nonlinearity is resonant. One should note here that  there are techniques  which  have  already  been developed to deal with resonant nonlinearity, and  although these techniques should prove to be very useful for the proposed research,  new methods  need to  be  developed to deal with additional difficulties.  The problems that the PI will investigate are 1)  the   Klein-Gordon-Zakharov system; 2) Gravity-Capillary Surface Waves; 3)  the asymptotic behavior of solutions to systems where the nonlinearities cause long-range effects. In addition to these projects, the PI will investigate  resonant dynamics and infinite volume approximation, where the final goal is to  derive a reduced system of equations for the effective dynamics of gravity waves in a 2-dimensional fluid on a large domain of size. The question that the PI wants  to address can be roughly stated as follows:  Given a system whose domain is a large box of size and with periodic boundary conditions, is there a simple system of equations that describe the dynamics of small solutions for a very long time? The time is, of course, assumed to be longer than what it takes for  a wave packet  to reach the boundary of the box. Solutions to  the proposed problems will require the development of new methods and techniques and the refinement of existing ones.

por.por_cntn:
Nonlinear Dispersive Equations and Wave Turbulence

In the mathematical exploration of wave equations, one encounters the intriguing phenomena of waves described by weakly nonlinear dispersive equations. These equations capture the intricate dynamics of waves with subtle nonlinear and dispersive effects. In the study of turbulence, a fascinating interplay of energy unfolds, marked by cascades between different scales. The theoretical framework to describe this involves studying the nonlinear interactions of random waves. Such investigations delve into the complex nature of wave interactions, offering a rich field for both theoretical exploration and experimental validation.

Wave Turbulence Theory (WTT) examines the statistical properties of solutions to weakly nonlinear dispersive equations and derives a Wave Kinetic Equation (WKE) that describes the evolution of the wave spectrum. The WKE has stationary power-law solutions analogous to the Kolmogorov spectrum of hydrodynamic turbulence, which describes energy cascades. These solutions are known as Kolmogorov–Zakharov (KZ) spectra. The KZ solutions place WTT within the domain of general turbulence, specifically in the context of strongly non-equilibrium statistical systems.

Research Focus

The principal investigator (PI) focused his research on two central questions:

  1. Emergence of the Wave Kinetic Equation (WKE) from Nonlinear Dispersive Equations.
  2. Evolution of Specific Spectra, such as the Kolmogorov-Zakharov (KZ) Spectrum, from Turbulent Weakly Nonlinear Dispersive Equations.

Key Results

Seminal Paper on WKE and NLS

  • Collaborators: J. Shatah, PIs Buckmaster, Germain, and Hani
  • Achievement: Provided the first mathematically rigorous proof of the emergence of the WKE for the Nonlinear Schrödinger Equation (NLS) on a periodic d-dimensional torus.

Numerical Investigation of Quintic NLS

  • Collaborators: J. Shatah, T. Buckmaster, J. Banks, A. Korotkevich, and G. Kovecic
  • Achievement: Conducted a thorough numerical investigation into the regimes of validity for the WKE for the quintic NLS.

Evolution of Small-Scale Dispersive Waves in Two-Dimensional Random Flow

  • Collaborators: Oliver Bühler, Jalal Shatah, Samuel Boury 
  • Objective: Investigate the evolution of dispersive wave packets in a random background flow in two dimensions, focusing on the transition between fast and slow waves due to the background flow.
  • Methodology: Assuming linear wave dynamics and using ray tracing techniques, the team studied the dynamics of wave packets.
  • Key Findings: 
    • Proposed a theoretical threshold for fast-slow wave transition based on phase conservation when the background flow is steady.
    • Numerical simulations of the ray tracing confirmed the theoretical threshold.

Inhomogeneous Wave Turbulence in Modified Nonlinear Schrödinger Equation

  • Collaborators: Jalal Shatah, Zaher Hani, Hui Zhu
  • Objective: Investigate inhomogeneous wave turbulence using a modified nonlinear Schrödinger equation.
  • Methodology: 
    • Introduced the Wick NLS, a simplified model for wave turbulence theory characterized by the absence of self-interactions in the correlation expansions of its solutions.
    • Derived several wave kinetic equations governing the effective statistical behavior of solutions in different regimes.
  • Key Findings: 
    • In the homogeneous setting (where initial correlation is translation invariant), obtained a wave kinetic equation similar to the one predicted by formal theory.
    • In the inhomogeneous setting, derived a wave kinetic equation describing the statistical behavior of wave packets, accounting for both their transport and collisions.
    • Discovered a new wave kinetic equation in a specific scaling regime, providing a more detailed collision picture.

Modified by: Jalal Shatah
